q1.value: Validation of the Short Critical Consciousness Scale (ShoCCS)

q3.value:
1. The central aim of this research is to create a short version of the Critical Consciousness Scale (CCS) (Short CCS, or ShoCCS). Using IRT, the long-form CCS measure is scrutinized for low-information and redundant items, in order to create a brief CC measure that efficiently measures critical reflection and critical action. 

2. Further, the ShoCCS attempts to incorporate a subscale measuring critical motivation. Items to measure critical motivation were developed for inclusion in the original CCS, yet this subscale was not previously validated.

q4.value:
• In a prior analysis (see prior work below), item response theory (IRT) was used to select a subset of items reliably measuring critical action, critical reflection, and critical egalitarianism. This study seeks to validate these shortened scales on a new set of data. As such, we hypothesize that the following three latent constructs can be reliably measured by the items below. We define reliability as a test information curve (TIC) above 4 for most values of theta. This roughly corresponds to a reliability estimate of 0.8 and above. Critical Action items are measured on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from I never did this to I did this at least once a week. Critical Reflection items are measured on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from Strongly Disagree to Strongly Agree. Critical Egalitarianism items are measured on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from Strongly Disagree to Strongly Agree. The items that measure these constructs are detailed below, using the item numbers from the original CCS.

Critical Action
Q24: I participated in a civil rights group or organization.
Q25: I participated in a political party, club, or organization.
Q27: Contacted a public official by phone, mail, or email to tell him/her how you felt about a social or political issue.
Q28: Joined a protest march, political demonstration, or political meeting.
Q32: Participated in a human rights, gay rights, or women’s rights organization or group. 

Critical Reflection
Q3: Certain racial or ethnic groups have fewer chances to get good jobs.
Q6: Certain racial or ethnic groups have fewer chances to get ahead.
Q7: Women have fewer chances to get ahead.
Q8: Poor people have fewer chances to get ahead.

Critical Egalitarianism
Q10: It would be good if groups could be equal.
Q11: Group equality should be our ideal.
Q12: All groups should be given an equal chance in life.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Data from this study was pooled from two distinct studies examining developmental processes among marginalized youth, each of which administered the long form CCS. The first study surveyed 159 youth from several large metropolitan areas, across the U.S. The second study surveyed 165 youth in a large U.S. city on the East Coast. Overall, our sample size includes 324 adolescents. 

A diverse sample of adolescent youth were recruited from local youth organizing groups in various cities across the United States and from youth leadership councils in New York City. We developed partnerships with these different organizations in order to track student’s participation and to survey them during their time in these organizations. This study, however, only uses data from wave 1 of the project. Data for wave 1 was collected during the fall of 2018

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: In this study, we are merging two datasets together to test our hypotheses. While we have examined descriptive statistics and conducted factor analyses on the datasets individually, we have not examined the combined dataset. Further, we have not conducted any IRT analyses on these data sources which is the main aim of the current study.

I.	Critical Reflection–Perceived Inequality, or the structural awareness of social inequality and the ways in which historical processes perpetuate modern day disparities was measured via 8 items: 
1.	Certain racial or ethnic groups have fewer chances to get a good high school education
2.	Poor children have fewer chances to get a good high school education 
3.	Certain racial or ethnic groups have fewer chances to get good jobs 
4.	Women have fewer chances to get good jobs 
5.	Poor people have fewer chances to get good jobs 
6.	Certain racial or ethnic groups have fewer chances to get ahead 
7.	Women have fewer chances to get ahead 
8.	Poor people have fewer chances to get ahead 
                     Participants responded on a scale of 1 = strongly disagree to 6 = strongly agree. 

II.	Critical Reflection–Egalitarianism, or the endorsement of societal equality was measured via 5 items:
1.	It is a good thing that certain groups are at the top and other groups are at the bottom
2.	It would be good if groups could be equal
3.	Group equality should be our ideal 
4.	All groups should be given an equal chance in life 
5.	We would have fewer problems if we treated people more equally
       Participants responded on a scale of 1 = strongly disagree to 6 = strongly agree.
III.	Critical Motivation, individuals’ perceived ability and responsibility to enact social change was measured via 9 items: 
1.	It is important for young people to speak out when an injustice has occurred
2.	Young people have an important role to play in making the world a better place
3.	It is important for young people to know what is going on in the world 
4.	Political issues are not relevant to people who are not old enough to vote 
5.	Political issues are not relevant to people who are not old enough to vote
6.	It is important to be an active and informed citizen 
7.	It is important to correct social and economic inequality 
8.	It is important to confront someone who says something that you think is racist or prejudiced
9.	It is my responsibility to get involved and make things better for society 
10.	People like me should participate in the political activity and decision making of our country
11.	It does not matter whether I participate in local organizations or political activity because so many other people are involved 
       Participants responded on a scale of 1 = strongly disagree to 6 = strongly agree.

IV.	Critical Action, sociopolitical action taken to rectify inequality was measured via 9 items: 
1.	Participated in a civil rights group or organization
2.	Participated in a political party, club or organization
3.	Wrote a letter to a school, community newspaper, or publication about a social or political issue
4.	Contracted a public official by phone, mail, or email to tell him or her how you felt about a social or political meeting 
5.	Joined in a protest march, political demonstration, or political meeting 
6.	Worked on a political campaign 
7.	Participated in a discussion about a social or political issue 
8.	Signed an email or written petition about a social or political issue 
9.	Participated in a human rights, gay rights, or women’s rights organization or group 
     Participants responded on a scale of 1 = strongly disagree to 6 = strongly agree.

•	We will use a two-parameter logistic (2PL) graded response model (GRM) to select items from the critical consciousness scale (CCS) offering the most information (I(θ)) across the broadest available range of the ability parameter θ. Graded response models are an extension of Item Response Theory (IRT) that adapt logit or probit link functions to progressive dichotomizations of a Likert scale model (i.e. 0 vs 1-4, 0-1 vs 2-4, 0-2 vs. 3-4, and 0-3 vs. 4). This study uses the logit link function. Two-parameter models allow for variation in location and discrimination, meaning that items in the CCS scale are free to measure participants with different ability levels θ (location), and can discriminate more strongly or weakly between participants above or below certain levels of θ (discrimination).

q21.value:
•	The hypotheses of this study are informed by prior knowledge of the factor structure from a different data source that uses the same Critical Consciousness Scale. In another study using this other data source, we used item response theory to shorten the Critical Consciousness Scale by approximately 50%. Items were selected for the shortened scale using a mixture of item information curves (IICs) and theory. Items were ranked by the amount of information (I(θ)) they exhibited along the full spectrum of ability (θ). Thereafter, the theoretical contribution of each item to the three subscales of critical consciousness described above were noted. Starting with the item exhibiting the most information for each subscale, items were selected until each unique theoretical contribution was exhausted. This process led to the following reliable shortened scale.

A set of items is said to be reliable whenever they collectively reflect the same underlying phenomenon. Common thresholds for measures of reliability range from a minimum of 0.6 to a desirable range of 0.9 to 1. This research strives for a reliability estimate for the final item set of at least 0.7. In order to accomplish this, the total test information derived from the GRM should be at least 2.33 (de Ayala, 2013).

q22.value: Both data sources contain pre and post data on all critical conscious (CC) measures. We will only be using data from the first wave (pre data), and therefore all wave two (post data) will be omitted.

q23.value: In our data, there are 13 of 324 participants with at least one missing item on critical motivation, 11 of 324 participants with at least one missing item on critical action, and 11 of 324 with at least one missing item on critical reflection. Since each scale will be considered separately within the GRM, any given scale is missing 4% or less of its data. Given such few missing data points, we will conduct analyses using Full Information Maximum Likelihood.

q24.value: Sample size permitting, there are a handful of additional analyses this study may consider. First, we may consider looking at confirmatory factor analyses (CFAs) following the item selection from the GRM. Given known fit quality of the CCS constructs within this data, we don’t anticipate a diminished fit from the smaller selection of items. Nevertheless, we may seek confirming evidence. Second, we may also consider MIMIC models or multiple group analysis to assess measurement bias across different groups, including differential measurement by data source. This analysis would offer additional insight into the comparative performance of these constructs across varying populations. Third, we may also seek to confirm shortened short scales for critical action and critical reflection found in a separate data source on a sample demographically distinct from those in this study.

summary.value:
Durational Timeline - Registration of DT2

This project investigates how people think about the temporal relation between two time intervals. There are logical systems such as Allen's Interval Calculus that break down the relations into a set of mutually exclusive categories. The subset of relations we focus on in the current experiment are: STARTS - 2 events starting simultaneously and ending asynchronously, FINISHES - 2 events starting asynchronously and ending simultaneously, DURING - 2 events starting asynchronously and ending asynchronously, and EQUALS - 2 events starting simultaneously and ending simultaneously. The initial analysis of generated descriptions from an earlier experiment (DT1) suggest that descriptions rarely are complete and unambiguous. By contrasting the acceptability of incomplete descriptions for intervals matching the above relations, the experiment is designed to show whether there is a bias in preferences for descriptions relations by either start times only or end times only, by the underlying temporal relation, and whether these factors interact.  The experimental task is a 2 alternative forced choice between 2 partial descriptions for 16 problems, 4 of each temporal relation type.  An example problem (given in the instructions) is: "Suppose the following is true: The installation started at 12pm and ended at 11pm on Friday. The download started at 9am and ended at 11pm on Friday. Which of the following is a better description? The download started before the installation started. The installation ended when the download ended." The temporal information is presented initially with the question and possible responses appearing after a 2 second delay. The two descriptions are presented on buttons that the participant clicks to indicate their response. The order of descriptions (started first or ended first) is randomized by problem. Both descriptions are always logically accurate. The experiment ends with two debriefing questions: one asking how the participant approached deciding between the two options and one open ended. Participants will be excluded for nonsensical debriefing responses (often indicating a bot instead of a human participant), for indicating they did not take the experiment seriously, or for response patterns such as always selecting the first response. This is the first experiment investigating participant endorsement of descriptions (the previous experiment in this series required generation of descriptions).  Therefore, we are not pre-registering hypotheses.  Our initial exploratory analysis will consist of contrasting timepoint (start vs end), relation (equals, starts, finishes, during), and their interaction.  We will use non-parametric tests of the factors individually, an omnibus ANOVA with appropriate post-hoc contrasts, and a linear mixed effect regression model with estimated marginal means for the post-hoc contrasts. At the time of this registration, we have begun collection of 50 participants via Amazon Mechanical Turk with a payment of $1.50.

attributes.title: Relaxation goal versus control (no goal) study

q1.value: Relaxation Goal vs. Control (no goal) study

q4.value: A salient goal will increase the choice of a goal-consistent product for the self compared to a control (no salient goal) condition. A salient goal will reduce the choice of a goal-consistent product for a social other compared to control (no salient goal) condition. This effect will not be affected by reactance, self-construal, need for uniqueness, self-consciousness, or concerns about being perceived lazy or selfish.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study will follow a 2X2 design. I will manipulate active goal: relaxation goal vs. no goal. Relaxation goal will be primed by viewing images from the website of a Swedish inspired relaxation spa Thermea. In the no-goal condition participants will view images of abstract geometric patterns. After that participants will answer several questionnaires and  move on to a choice task. Participants will select either a relaxing or energizing tea from David's Tea either to for themselves or for a friend. Participants in the choice for friend condition will record a name of a friend they would like to give the chosen product to before viewing the options. One of the participants will be randomly chosen to receive the chosen product. I predict that among participants who are choosing for themselves, priming a relaxation goal will increase the likelihood of choice of a relaxing tea. Among participants who are choosing for a friend, priming a relaxation goal will reduce the likelihood of choosing a relaxing tea.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to relaxation goal vs. no goal condition and to choice for self vs. choice for friend condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: I will recruit participants through Amazon's Mechanical Turk. I will recruit participants residing in the USA  at the time of data collection with 95% or greater hit approval rating. All participants who take the study will be paid $0.75. Data will be collected on a week day morning. No further eligibility screening is anticipated. The data collection effort is anticipated to take several hours.

q13.value: I intend to recruit about 400 participants for this study.

q14.value: This sample size provides 100 participants per condition, which should provide sufficient power  to detect the effects.

question.value:
Goal: relaxation vs. no goal. 
Choice recipient: self vs. friend

Mood: At this moment, to what extent do you feel: happy, optimistic, empowered, hopeful, helpless, excited, overall positive (1= Not at all, 7 = Very much so)

Reactance: Hong & Faedda 1996 (1=Strongly disagree, 7 = Strongly agree) 

Self-construal: Singelis 1994 (1=Strongly disagree, 7 = Strongly agree) 

Active goal: At this moment, to what extent would you say you have the following goals on your mind: To do well professionally, to relax, to have fun, to save time (1= Not at all, 7 = Very much so)

Self-consciousness (Scheier & Carver, 2013) (abbreviated scale):  care a lot about how I present myself to others, I am constantly thinking about my reasons for doing things, I sometimes step back (in my mind) in order to examine myself from a distance, I am concerned about what other people think of me (1=Strongly disagree, 7 = Strongly agree) 

Concerns about being perceived selfish, lazy: When I decide what to do I think about whether or not other people will interpret it as "being selfish", When I decide what to do I think about whether or not other people will interpret it as "being lazy" (1=Strongly disagree, 7 = Strongly agree) 

Need for uniqueness (Tian, Bearden, & Hunter, 2001) (1=Strongly disagree, 7 = Strongly agree)


Binary choice of product

To what extent is each of the following tea options instrumental is helping a person make progress toward their goal to relax? Lime Wire Lemon, Pura Vida (1= Not at all, 7 = Very much so).

I will analyse whether goal condition influenced mood using an ANOVA. I will analyze binary choice using logistic regression with goal, choice recipient and the interaction as predictors. I will analyze the potential covariates (self-construal, reactance, need for uniqueness, self-consciousness, concerns about being perceived as lazy, selfish) first by testing whether they interact with active goal and recipient on binary choice after that I will include them as covariates in the original model to see if they reduce significance of the original focal effect. Logistic regression will be used to perform these analyses. I will analyze the perceived relevance of choice options to the relaxation goal using a repeated measures ANOVA.

attributes.title: How Hate Speech Prosecution Affects Citizens’ Democratic Support: A Comparative Study Between the United States and the Netherlands

q1.value: How Hate Speech Prosecution Affects Citizens' Democratic Support: A Comparative Study Between the United States and the Netherlands

q2.value: Lisanne Wichgers, Laura	Jacobs, Joost van spanje

q3.value:
Background. 

Throughout the past decades, several anti-immigration politicians in Europe have faced legal prosecution for inciting hatred. Examples are the Dutch Geert Wilders (Freedom Party (PVV)) and the Belgian Daniel Féret (Démocratie Nationale). The intended outcomes of hate speech prosecution include protecting the rights of (ethnic, racial and religious) minorities and immigrants, thereby warning political actors seeking to violate this democratic principle. However, recent studies have emphasized that hate speech prosecution may also have unintended consequences, such as boosting party’s electoral performance and decreasing citizens’ democratic support (authors, 2020; Van Spanje and De Vreese, 2014; 2015). The decision to (not) prosecute a politician for hate speech has been found to decrease democratic support for some, but not for other citizens depending on citizens’ attitude regarding immigration. Prior findings suggest that it is the political idea spread by the alleged hate speech that is relevant, not the party or the politician: while confrontation with the prosecution of an anti-immigration politician seems to decrease democratic support among citizens with strong anti-immigration attitudes, it seems to increase democratic support among citizens that are pro-immigration. The opposite was observed for the decision not to prosecute the politician for hate speech: citizens with pro-immigration attitudes lost democratic support, whereas democratic support increased among citizens with strong anti-immigration attitudes.

However, previous research has only been conducted in the Dutch context. The Netherlands has a multi-party system, with numerous political parties. Moreover, issues regarding immigration and integration have been highly salient in the past, and still are. Political ideas – in particular when they concern salient issues – are therefore generally perceived as more important than identification with a party or a politician, as was also evident from prior research about the effects of hate speech prosecution (authors, 2020; Van Spanje and De Vreese, 2014; 2015). Furthermore, many Dutch citizens believe that free speech should be restricted when being hurtful to groups of people (authors, 2020). To test if the previous findings hold, i.e., whether the political idea is indeed the main driver behind the effects, we need to test our hypotheses in a context that is different with regard to important extraneous variables. This means studying a country with a two-party system, where partisan identities are arguably stronger, and, subsequently, agreement with the political is generally deemed less important. Furthermore, as curbing discrimination is, by Dutch law, protected more than free speech, we need a country where the reverse is true.

A cross-cultural study between the Netherlands and the United States provides a great opportunity to test the mechanisms underlying previous findings, as 1) due to the two-party system and high levels of affective polarization, partisan identification is arguably stronger in the US than in the Netherlands, and 2) free speech is a core American value and protected much more in the US than in the Netherlands. Hence, the US functions as a ‘least likely case’. By studying the effects of the decision to (not) prosecute a politician for hate speech in two very different environments, we advance our understanding of the underlying mechanisms.

Purpose of study. 

The purpose of this study is to examine the mechanisms underlying the relationship between hate speech prosecution and democratic support in more detail. By examining the effects of hate speech prosecution on democratic support in two profoundly different contexts, we aim to discern what is exactly driving the effects: to what extent do agreement with the political ideas spread by the politician, identification with the prosecuted politician’s party and adherence to free speech explain how citizens respond to the decision to (not) prosecute a politician for hate speech? 

Broad research questions. 

What are the effects of the decision to (not) prosecute a politician for hate speech on democratic support, and what is the moderating role of agreement with the politician’s political ideas, party identification and adherence to free speech? The next paragraph will elaborate on our expectations regarding the similarities and differences between the two contexts.

q4.value:
Effects of the decision to prosecute a politician for hate speech. 

H1: The decision to prosecute a politician for hate speech decreases democratic support among citizens with more negative attitudes toward immigrants.  
H2: The decision to prosecute a politician for hate speech decreases democratic support among citizens who identify with the prosecuted politician’s party or ideologically close parties. 
H3: The decision to prosecute a politician for hate speech decreases democratic support the more citizens prioritize free speech over protecting minorities from discrimination.

Effects of a decision to not prosecute a politician for hate speech. 

H4: The decision to not prosecute a politician for hate speech decreases democratic support among citizens with more positive attitudes toward immigrants.
H5: The decision to not prosecute a politician for hate speech decreases democratic support among citizens who identify with the opposing party or ideologically distant parties. 
H6: The decision to not prosecute a politician for hate speech decreases democratic support the more citizens prioritize protecting minorities from discrimination over free speech.

Differences in the strength of effects between the Netherlands and the US.

H7: The decrease in democratic support following the decision to prosecute a politician for hate speech will be stronger among Dutch citizens with more negative attitudes toward immigrants than among American citizens.
H8: The decrease in democratic support following the decision to prosecute a politician for hate speech will be stronger for American citizens who identify with the prosecuted politician’s party than for Dutch citizens who identify with the prosecuted politician’s party or ideologically close parties.
H9: The decrease in democratic support following the decision to prosecute a politician for hate speech will be stronger among American citizens who prioritize free speech over protecting minorities from discrimination than among Dutch citizens.
H10: The decrease in democratic support following the decision to not prosecute a politician for hate speech will be stronger among Dutch citizens with more positive attitudes toward immigrants than among American citizens. 
H11: The decrease in democratic support following the decision to not prosecute a politician for hate speech will be stronger among American citizens who identify with the opposing party than for Dutch citizens who identify with the opposing party or ideologically distant parties.
H12: The decrease in democratic support following the decision to not prosecute a politician for hate speech will be stronger among Dutch citizens who prioritize protecting minorities from discrimination over free speech than among American citizens.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We designed a web-experiment to test our hypotheses. The experiment relies on a between-subjects design, where participants are randomly assigned to one of four conditions: two experimental conditions in which the independent variable (‘Decision to (not) prosecute’) is manipulated and two control conditions. The control conditions are necessary as experimental conditions need to be compared with a situation without any treatment or manipulation of the independent variable, to fully understand the ramifications of the decision to (not) prosecute politicians for hate speech. To test our hypotheses, the experimental conditions will be compared with the first control condition, where the hate speech is mentioned but without further information about the decision to (not) prosecute the politician. The rationale behind this is that the only factor that is different from the experimental manipulations is that there is no reference to hate speech prosecution. The second control condition replaces the story about hate speech (prosecution) by a neutral news story. To test the effect of priming, both control conditions are needed.

q9.value: Participants are randomly assigned to the four conditions by Qualtrics. This should result in an approximately equal number of participants in each condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: The data have been collected in Qualtrics, but the data have not been observed yet.

question.value:
The study relies on data from human subjects. The sample consists of Dutch citizens (50%) and American citizens (50%).

The experiment is embedded in an online questionnaire. We have collaborated with the survey firm Dynata (formerly SSI) for data collection. Dynata has an established Internet interviewing infrastructure and regularly conducts these types of surveys using their infrastructure. All members of Dynata panels agree to the same terms and conditions and go through the same recruitment process. We have asked Dynata to invite samples of participants, aged 18 or older, and representative on age, gender and area of residence. This was done in an attempt to mirror the demographics of adults in the general population of the Netherlands and the United States who are eligible to vote. If additional covariates – for instance, political behavior – are unequally divided over the conditions, we will control for these in subsequent analyses.

Dynata compensated panelists based on the amount of time or effort participants spent completing a questionnaire. Incentives are provided in the form of points or dollars and entries into prize draws and sweepstakes.

q13.value: We have collected complete responses from 1211 participants: 601 American participants and 610 Dutch citizens.

q14.value: We have conducted a power analysis to calculate the required sample size for testing the hypotheses. A minimum of 93 participants per condition is needed to test our hypotheses. The current sample size (approximately 150 per condition) is therefore deemed to be large enough to test the aforementioned twelve hypotheses. A larger sample was not possible due to financial restrictions.

q15.value: A stopping rule is not applicable due to the fixed sample size (1200). Data collection was stopped when 1211 participants (610 Dutch and 601 Americans) completed the questionnaire.

question.value: The independent variable is the decision to (not) prosecute a politician for hate speech. The two levels of this variable are (1) the decision to prosecute and (2) the decision to not prosecute a politician for hate speech. This is manipulated by means of a news story. The news story of the first experimental condition describes that an existing (Dutch or American) anti-immigration politician will be prosecuted for spreading hateful messages about Muslims. The news story of the second experimental condition mentions that the politician will not be prosecuted for spreading hateful messages about Muslims. In the control condition there is a mentioning of the politician having spread hateful messages about Muslims, but without any further information about the decision to (not) prosecute the politician. The Dutch news story refers to Forum for Democracy (Forum voor Democratie, FvD) MP Theo Hiddema. While the party presents itself mainly as an anti-establishment, anti-European Union (EU) party, it perceives immigration as highly problematic and believes that “foreigners” and ethnic minorities should assimilate with the dominant Dutch culture. The American news story refers to David Perdue, a Republican senator (Georgia) who openly expressed strong anti-immigration attitudes. The articles were made as similar to existing news outlets (NU.nl for the Dutch participants, Yahoo! News for the American participants) as possible, by using an approximately similar layout. A pilot study among Dutch university students (n = 275) demonstrated that the design was successful and that participants could not guess the study’s exact goal.

Democratic support. 

The outcome variable is democratic support. To account for the multidimensionality of democratic support, we operationalize democratic support using four dimensions. These dimensions are largely based on four of the dimensions outlined by Norris (2011), and range from more diffuse (abstract) forms of democratic support to more specific (concrete) forms of democratic support.

The most diffuse form of democratic support in this study is “system affect”, which involves a citizen’s belief that the democratic system defends the basic democratic norms and values a person believes in (Muller and Williams, 1980). This is largely in line with Norris’ “approval of core regime principles and values”. This is measured by the Political Support-Alienation Scale (Muller, Jukam and Seligson, 1982). This scale consists of the following three (originally eight) items (7-point Likert scale from 1 (‘completely disagree’) to 7 (‘completely agree’)): “To what extent do you feel that the fundamental rights of citizens are well protected by our democratic constitutional state?”; “To what extent are you proud to live under our democratic constitutional state?”; “To what extent do you feel that you and your close ones are well represented by our democratic constitutional state?”.

The second dimension is “evaluations of democratic performance”, and represents the meso level of democratic support – the dimension that seems most difficult to measure (Norris, 2011). Evaluations of democratic performance are measured via three items (7-point scale from ‘fully disagree’ to ‘fully agree’): “In a democracy, the economic system functions badly”; “Democracies are indecisive and there is too much quibbling”; “Democracies are not good in maintaining order”. The answers will be recoded to a higher value indicating more democratic support. These items replace the more common ‘satisfaction with democracy’-item, measuring how citizens evaluate the functioning of democratic states without necessarily having to disregard general democratic principles (Linde and Ekman, 2003; Norris, 2011).

The final two dimensions are “confidence in state institutions” (11-point scale) and “trust in politicians” (similar to Norris’ “approval of incumbent office-holders” measure) (7-point scale). These two dimensions represent the most specific forms of democratic support. Confidence in state institutions is measured by the following question: “Please describe on a scale from 0 (‘no trust at all’) to 10 (‘very strong trust’) how much you personally trust each of the institutions”, followed by the following political institutions: parliament (/congress), the Public Prosecutor (/federal prosecutors) and the government (the first two originating from the European Social Survey (ESS)). Trust in politicians is measured by the following three items (7-point Likert scale from 1 (‘completely disagree’) to 7 (‘completely agree’)): “Most politicians give up their ideals or break their promises to gain more power”; “Most politicians talk much but do little to solve the real important problems in this country”; “Most politicians are in politics for personal gain”. This scale is a shortened version of the original Political Cynicism Scale (Citrin and Elkins, 1975). The answers will be recoded afterwards to higher values indicating more trust in politicians.

We will perform a principal component analysis with principal axis factoring (using Oblimin rotation) to test if the aforementioned items form the four dimensions as intended.

Immigrant attitudes.

Attitudes to immigrants will be included as a moderator variable. We ask participants to evaluate four statements about immigrants and immigration, measured on a 11-point scale: “Is the Netherlands (/United States) made a worse or a better place to live by people coming to live here from other countries?” (0 (‘worse’), 10 (‘better’)), “Would you say it is generally bad or good for the Dutch (/American) economy that people from different countries come to live here?” (0 (‘bad’), 10 (‘good’)), “Would you say that cultural life in the Netherlands (/United States) is generally undermined or enriched by people coming to live here from other countries?” (0 (‘undermined’), 10 (‘enriched’)) and “Are crime problems in the Netherlands (/United States) made worse or better by people coming to live here from other countries?” (0 (‘worse’), 10 (‘better’)). These items originate from the European Social Survey (ESS). The former three items form a validated scale, but we will perform a principal component analysis to test whether the factor loading of the last item is sufficiently high. 

In addition to the aforementioned scale, we include several other operationalizations of attitudes toward outgroups and generalized prejudice in the survey. These will be used as robustness checks, as we expect that the various measurements are positively correlated and should therefore yield similar results.  

We include a feeling thermometer to measure participants’ feelings toward various groups in society (ranging on a scale from 0 (‘very negative’) to 100 (‘very positive’)). The American participants were asked about their feelings toward Muslims, Jews, Christians, Democrats, Republicans and LGBT. The Dutch participants were asked about their feelings toward Muslims, Jews, Christians, Right-wing conservatives, Left-wing progressives, LHBT and the Dutch. The primary aim of this variable is measuring to what extent attitudes toward immigrants align with feelings toward various outgroups, in particular Muslims, as the news story refers to messages about Muslims.

We measure attitudes toward multiculturalism, by the following item: “Some people think that persons with a migration background in the Netherlands (/United States) should be able to live while preserving all habits and traditions of their own culture. Others think they should fully adapt to the Dutch (/American) culture. What do you think?” (measured on a scale from 0 (‘Preserve culture of persons with migration background’) to 10 (‘Adapt to Dutch (/American) culture’)). 

Party identification.

Party identification will be included as a moderator variable. Party identification is measured by party support, vote choice, affective and cognitive components of party identification and ideological distance of the political party. We include multiple operationalizations of party identification as robustness checks.

We measure party support by the following question: “Some people perceive themselves as a supporter of a specific political party, others do not perceive themselves as a supporter of a party. Do you perceive yourself as a supporter of a party, or not?”. If participants report to support a party, a follow-up question asks which party the participant perceives him/herself to be a supporter of. Subsequently, we ask how strong the participant perceives him/herself to be a supporter of this party (on a scale from 1 (‘supporter, but not very strong’) to 7 (‘very strong supporter’)).

We measure vote choice by the question “Did you vote during the last national election (2017) (/presidential election (2016))?”. If participants report having voted, a question follows asking for which party (/candidate) the participant voted. 

The party identification scale specifically refers to FvD (/Republican party), but the same questions are also repeated for another political party (D66 (center party)) (/Democrat party) (order of parties randomized). The scale is an adapted version of Mael and Tetrick’s (1992) ‘Identification with a Psychological Group’ (IDPG) scale, established in social psychology and proven to be applicable to political parties (Brewer and Silver, 2000; Ohr and Quandt, 2012). The scale includes four items on a 7-point Likert scale (from 1 (‘completely disagree’) to 7 (‘completely agree’)): “If someone criticizes the Forum for Democracy (/Republican party), this feels as a personal assault”; “If I talk about the Forum for Democracy (/Republican party), I say “we” instead of “I””; “The successes of the Forum for Democracy (/Republican party) are my successes”; “If someone praises the Forum for Democracy (/Republican party), this feels as a personal compliment”. Higher scores thus correspond to stronger identification with the party of the prosecuted politician.

Furthermore, we include a measure of left-right (/liberal-conservative) placement of various political parties, and a measure of self-placement on the left-right (/liberal-conservative) political spectrum. By combining these, we can use this as a measurement of ideological distance of the FvD/Republican party.

Free speech versus protecting minorities.

We include an item that explicitly measures to what extent participants prioritize protecting free speech over protecting minorities from discrimination: “To what extent do you think it is more important that people are able to say everything publicly, or that minorities have to be protected from discrimination?” Answers are coded on a 7-point Likert-scale, from 1 (‘protecting free speech’) to 7 (‘protecting minorities from discrimination’).

For the following variables, we will take the mean of the items described in the previous paragraph to create a single mean per variable.

-	Democratic support: System affect (3 items); Evaluations of democratic performance (3 items); Confidence in state institutions (3 items); Trust in politicians (3 items)
-	Immigrant attitudes: Attitudes to immigrants (4 items)
-	Party identification: Affective/cognitive identification (4 items).

Prior to creating scales, we will calculate the reliability of the items. Furthermore, we will conduct principal component analyses with principal axis factoring (using Oblimin rotation).

A multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) will be conducted to examine mean differences between the conditions for the four dimensions of democratic support. MANCOVA (multivariate analysis of covariance) are used for the moderation analyses. For H1, H2, H3, H7, H8 and H9 the categorical independent variable is the decision to prosecute a politician for hate speech, and the different dimensions of democratic support are included as continuous dependent variables. For H1 and H7 we include immigrant attitudes as a moderator, and the moderator for H2 and H8 is party identification. For H3 and H9 we include the balance between free speech and protecting minorities as a moderator.

For H4, H5, H6, H10, H11 and H12 the categorical independent variable is the decision to not prosecute a politician for hate speech, and the different dimensions of democratic support are included as continuous dependent variables. For H4 and H10 immigrant attitudes is included as the moderator. For H5 and H11 we include party identification as a moderator. H6 and H12 include the balance between free speech and protecting minorities as a moderator.

q20.value: The items that measure “Evaluations of democratic performance” and “Trust in politicians” will be recoded afterwards, higher scores indicating a more positive evaluation of democratic performance and higher trust in politicians.

q21.value: The standard p < 0.05 criteria will be used for determining if the MANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The p-values will be supplemented by effect sizes.

q22.value: Outliers will be included in the analysis. We will test if including and excluding outliers yield different results.

q23.value: Participants with missing values will be excluded from the corresponding analyses (listwise deletion).

registration_responses.q22: Outliers will be included in the analysis. We will test if including and excluding outliers yield different results.
registration_responses.q23: Participants with missing values will be excluded from the corresponding analyses (listwise deletion).
registration_responses.q8.question: We designed a web-experiment to test our hypotheses. The experiment relies on a between-subjects design, where participants are randomly assigned to one of four conditions: two experimental conditions in which the independent variable (‘Decision to (not) prosecute’) is manipulated and two control conditions. The control conditions are necessary as experimental conditions need to be compared with a situation without any treatment or manipulation of the independent variable, to fully understand the ramifications of the decision to (not) prosecute politicians for hate speech. To test our hypotheses, the experimental conditions will be compared with the first control condition, where the hate speech is mentioned but without further information about the decision to (not) prosecute the politician. The rationale behind this is that the only factor that is different from the experimental manipulations is that there is no reference to hate speech prosecution. The second control condition replaces the story about hate speech (prosecution) by a neutral news story. To test the effect of priming, both control conditions are needed.
registration_responses.q12.question:
The study relies on data from human subjects. The sample consists of Dutch citizens (50%) and American citizens (50%).

The experiment is embedded in an online questionnaire. We have collaborated with the survey firm Dynata (formerly SSI) for data collection. Dynata has an established Internet interviewing infrastructure and regularly conducts these types of surveys using their infrastructure. All members of Dynata panels agree to the same terms and conditions and go through the same recruitment process. We have asked Dynata to invite samples of participants, aged 18 or older, and representative on age, gender and area of residence. This was done in an attempt to mirror the demographics of adults in the general population of the Netherlands and the United States who are eligible to vote. If additional covariates – for instance, political behavior – are unequally divided over the conditions, we will control for these in subsequent analyses.

Dynata compensated panelists based on the amount of time or effort participants spent completing a questionnaire. Incentives are provided in the form of points or dollars and entries into prize draws and sweepstakes.
registration_responses.q16.question: The independent variable is the decision to (not) prosecute a politician for hate speech. The two levels of this variable are (1) the decision to prosecute and (2) the decision to not prosecute a politician for hate speech. This is manipulated by means of a news story. The news story of the first experimental condition describes that an existing (Dutch or American) anti-immigration politician will be prosecuted for spreading hateful messages about Muslims. The news story of the second experimental condition mentions that the politician will not be prosecuted for spreading hateful messages about Muslims. In the control condition there is a mentioning of the politician having spread hateful messages about Muslims, but without any further information about the decision to (not) prosecute the politician. The Dutch news story refers to Forum for Democracy (Forum voor Democratie, FvD) MP Theo Hiddema. While the party presents itself mainly as an anti-establishment, anti-European Union (EU) party, it perceives immigration as highly problematic and believes that “foreigners” and ethnic minorities should assimilate with the dominant Dutch culture. The American news story refers to David Perdue, a Republican senator (Georgia) who openly expressed strong anti-immigration attitudes. The articles were made as similar to existing news outlets (NU.nl for the Dutch participants, Yahoo! News for the American participants) as possible, by using an approximately similar layout. A pilot study among Dutch university students (n = 275) demonstrated that the design was successful and that participants could not guess the study’s exact goal.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Democratic support. 

The outcome variable is democratic support. To account for the multidimensionality of democratic support, we operationalize democratic support using four dimensions. These dimensions are largely based on four of the dimensions outlined by Norris (2011), and range from more diffuse (abstract) forms of democratic support to more specific (concrete) forms of democratic support.

The most diffuse form of democratic support in this study is “system affect”, which involves a citizen’s belief that the democratic system defends the basic democratic norms and values a person believes in (Muller and Williams, 1980). This is largely in line with Norris’ “approval of core regime principles and values”. This is measured by the Political Support-Alienation Scale (Muller, Jukam and Seligson, 1982). This scale consists of the following three (originally eight) items (7-point Likert scale from 1 (‘completely disagree’) to 7 (‘completely agree’)): “To what extent do you feel that the fundamental rights of citizens are well protected by our democratic constitutional state?”; “To what extent are you proud to live under our democratic constitutional state?”; “To what extent do you feel that you and your close ones are well represented by our democratic constitutional state?”.

The second dimension is “evaluations of democratic performance”, and represents the meso level of democratic support – the dimension that seems most difficult to measure (Norris, 2011). Evaluations of democratic performance are measured via three items (7-point scale from ‘fully disagree’ to ‘fully agree’): “In a democracy, the economic system functions badly”; “Democracies are indecisive and there is too much quibbling”; “Democracies are not good in maintaining order”. The answers will be recoded to a higher value indicating more democratic support. These items replace the more common ‘satisfaction with democracy’-item, measuring how citizens evaluate the functioning of democratic states without necessarily having to disregard general democratic principles (Linde and Ekman, 2003; Norris, 2011).

The final two dimensions are “confidence in state institutions” (11-point scale) and “trust in politicians” (similar to Norris’ “approval of incumbent office-holders” measure) (7-point scale). These two dimensions represent the most specific forms of democratic support. Confidence in state institutions is measured by the following question: “Please describe on a scale from 0 (‘no trust at all’) to 10 (‘very strong trust’) how much you personally trust each of the institutions”, followed by the following political institutions: parliament (/congress), the Public Prosecutor (/federal prosecutors) and the government (the first two originating from the European Social Survey (ESS)). Trust in politicians is measured by the following three items (7-point Likert scale from 1 (‘completely disagree’) to 7 (‘completely agree’)): “Most politicians give up their ideals or break their promises to gain more power”; “Most politicians talk much but do little to solve the real important problems in this country”; “Most politicians are in politics for personal gain”. This scale is a shortened version of the original Political Cynicism Scale (Citrin and Elkins, 1975). The answers will be recoded afterwards to higher values indicating more trust in politicians.

We will perform a principal component analysis with principal axis factoring (using Oblimin rotation) to test if the aforementioned items form the four dimensions as intended.

Immigrant attitudes.

Attitudes to immigrants will be included as a moderator variable. We ask participants to evaluate four statements about immigrants and immigration, measured on a 11-point scale: “Is the Netherlands (/United States) made a worse or a better place to live by people coming to live here from other countries?” (0 (‘worse’), 10 (‘better’)), “Would you say it is generally bad or good for the Dutch (/American) economy that people from different countries come to live here?” (0 (‘bad’), 10 (‘good’)), “Would you say that cultural life in the Netherlands (/United States) is generally undermined or enriched by people coming to live here from other countries?” (0 (‘undermined’), 10 (‘enriched’)) and “Are crime problems in the Netherlands (/United States) made worse or better by people coming to live here from other countries?” (0 (‘worse’), 10 (‘better’)). These items originate from the European Social Survey (ESS). The former three items form a validated scale, but we will perform a principal component analysis to test whether the factor loading of the last item is sufficiently high. 

In addition to the aforementioned scale, we include several other operationalizations of attitudes toward outgroups and generalized prejudice in the survey. These will be used as robustness checks, as we expect that the various measurements are positively correlated and should therefore yield similar results.  

We include a feeling thermometer to measure participants’ feelings toward various groups in society (ranging on a scale from 0 (‘very negative’) to 100 (‘very positive’)). The American participants were asked about their feelings toward Muslims, Jews, Christians, Democrats, Republicans and LGBT. The Dutch participants were asked about their feelings toward Muslims, Jews, Christians, Right-wing conservatives, Left-wing progressives, LHBT and the Dutch. The primary aim of this variable is measuring to what extent attitudes toward immigrants align with feelings toward various outgroups, in particular Muslims, as the news story refers to messages about Muslims.

We measure attitudes toward multiculturalism, by the following item: “Some people think that persons with a migration background in the Netherlands (/United States) should be able to live while preserving all habits and traditions of their own culture. Others think they should fully adapt to the Dutch (/American) culture. What do you think?” (measured on a scale from 0 (‘Preserve culture of persons with migration background’) to 10 (‘Adapt to Dutch (/American) culture’)). 

Party identification.

Party identification will be included as a moderator variable. Party identification is measured by party support, vote choice, affective and cognitive components of party identification and ideological distance of the political party. We include multiple operationalizations of party identification as robustness checks.

We measure party support by the following question: “Some people perceive themselves as a supporter of a specific political party, others do not perceive themselves as a supporter of a party. Do you perceive yourself as a supporter of a party, or not?”. If participants report to support a party, a follow-up question asks which party the participant perceives him/herself to be a supporter of. Subsequently, we ask how strong the participant perceives him/herself to be a supporter of this party (on a scale from 1 (‘supporter, but not very strong’) to 7 (‘very strong supporter’)).

We measure vote choice by the question “Did you vote during the last national election (2017) (/presidential election (2016))?”. If participants report having voted, a question follows asking for which party (/candidate) the participant voted. 

The party identification scale specifically refers to FvD (/Republican party), but the same questions are also repeated for another political party (D66 (center party)) (/Democrat party) (order of parties randomized). The scale is an adapted version of Mael and Tetrick’s (1992) ‘Identification with a Psychological Group’ (IDPG) scale, established in social psychology and proven to be applicable to political parties (Brewer and Silver, 2000; Ohr and Quandt, 2012). The scale includes four items on a 7-point Likert scale (from 1 (‘completely disagree’) to 7 (‘completely agree’)): “If someone criticizes the Forum for Democracy (/Republican party), this feels as a personal assault”; “If I talk about the Forum for Democracy (/Republican party), I say “we” instead of “I””; “The successes of the Forum for Democracy (/Republican party) are my successes”; “If someone praises the Forum for Democracy (/Republican party), this feels as a personal compliment”. Higher scores thus correspond to stronger identification with the party of the prosecuted politician.

Furthermore, we include a measure of left-right (/liberal-conservative) placement of various political parties, and a measure of self-placement on the left-right (/liberal-conservative) political spectrum. By combining these, we can use this as a measurement of ideological distance of the FvD/Republican party.

Free speech versus protecting minorities.

We include an item that explicitly measures to what extent participants prioritize protecting free speech over protecting minorities from discrimination: “To what extent do you think it is more important that people are able to say everything publicly, or that minorities have to be protected from discrimination?” Answers are coded on a 7-point Likert-scale, from 1 (‘protecting free speech’) to 7 (‘protecting minorities from discrimination’).
registration_responses.q18.question:
For the following variables, we will take the mean of the items described in the previous paragraph to create a single mean per variable.

-	Democratic support: System affect (3 items); Evaluations of democratic performance (3 items); Confidence in state institutions (3 items); Trust in politicians (3 items)
-	Immigrant attitudes: Attitudes to immigrants (4 items)
-	Party identification: Affective/cognitive identification (4 items).

Prior to creating scales, we will calculate the reliability of the items. Furthermore, we will conduct principal component analyses with principal axis factoring (using Oblimin rotation).
registration_responses.q19.question:
A multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) will be conducted to examine mean differences between the conditions for the four dimensions of democratic support. MANCOVA (multivariate analysis of covariance) are used for the moderation analyses. For H1, H2, H3, H7, H8 and H9 the categorical independent variable is the decision to prosecute a politician for hate speech, and the different dimensions of democratic support are included as continuous dependent variables. For H1 and H7 we include immigrant attitudes as a moderator, and the moderator for H2 and H8 is party identification. For H3 and H9 we include the balance between free speech and protecting minorities as a moderator.

For H4, H5, H6, H10, H11 and H12 the categorical independent variable is the decision to not prosecute a politician for hate speech, and the different dimensions of democratic support are included as continuous dependent variables. For H4 and H10 immigrant attitudes is included as the moderator. For H5 and H11 we include party identification as a moderator. H6 and H12 include the balance between free speech and protecting minorities as a moderator.

attributes.title: Confirmation Bias in Politics and Religion

q1.value: Comparing the confirmation bias in politics and religion

q3.value:
The confirmation bias exists when we selectively choose information that aligns with pre-existing viewpoints.  Relatedly, it is also manifest when we see information or hear arguments that run counter to our preexisting  viewpoints and, as a result, we tend to view that information or argument as less valuable or less persuasive.

The confirmation bias has been documented in the realm of political attitudes, but this project seeks to document the bias in the realms of both politics and religion and compare their relative strength.  I also intend to test the hypothesis that this bias is promoted through deliberation (i.e., a more reflective thinking style), as opposed to being a more typical automatic-thought decision bias.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1a:  Individuals who are more liberal (conservative) in political ideology will select to view more liberal-leaning (conservative-leaning) information on the political issue of gun control.
Hypothesis 1b:  When required to view arguments counter to one's political ideology, individuals will perceive those arguments as more weak
Hypothesis 2a:  Those who self-identify as Christian (non-religious) in their religious beliefs will choose to view more arguments on the existence of God from Christian (atheist) sources
Hypothesis 2b:  When required to view arguments counter to one's viewpoint on the existence or non-existence of God, individuals will perceive those arguments as more weak.
Hypothesis 3:  The confirmation bias will not differ in strength in the political versus religious viewpoints domain.
Hypothesis 4:  Confirmation bias evidence will be stronger for those who have put more thought into the issue (gun control or the existence of God).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Using the Prolific subject pool, we will construct 4 separate treatments  and filter the recruitment pool by religion and political ideology.  In this way, there will be 4 treatments to this study defined by "Political ideology & Religious beliefs": Conservative & Christian, Conservative & Non-Religious, Liberal & Christian, Liberal & Non-Religious (i.e., the two factors we manipulate in the subjects recruited are political ideology (Conservative or Liberal) and religious beliefs (Christian or Non-Religious) to create a 2x2 between subjects experimental study).  

We will recruit equal numbers of participants from each treatment group to complete a common survey that contains the information search and argument ratings task needed to identify the confirmation bias and test hypotheses 1 and 2.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Subjects will be recruited on the Prolific subject pool.  Self-identified political ideology and religious beliefs are filter criteria on Prolific and allow one to equal samples sizes on these two dimensions by conducted 4 separate studies (one for each of the 4 cells in the 2x2 design).  
The other selection criteria will be: over 18 years of age, and the individual must have self-reported voting in a previous U.S. Presidential Election

q13.value: Plan is to recruit n=400 individuals balanced across the 4 design cells.  Thus, we will recruit n=100 or each of the 4 subject treatment categories ("Political ideology + Religious beliefs")

q14.value:
Sample size was chosen to balance budget constraint, and having sufficient sample size in each design cell to conduct analysis conditioning on at least one other measured co-variate (e.g., gender or cognitive reflection style).

For pilot-testing the length of the survey (necessary to set payments appropriately, I will run an n=10 participant study on Prolific using the Liberal & NonReligiou design cell filters.  These pilot subjects' data will not be analyzed as part of the study.  Rather, the purpose of the pilot data is for compensation level (Prolific has a minimum compensation rate)

q15.value: Based on current data from Prolific, there are significantly less active survey responders in their subject pool who self identify as both Conservative & NonReligious (e.g., < 10% the number of these active Prolific survey takers compared to those who self-identify as Liberal & NonReligious).  As such, there is the possibility it may be difficult to acquire a full n=100 participants in this design cell.  Current data shows 166 active survey takers in Prolific who are Conservative & NonReligious and so hopefully this is not an issue, but there may be an unplanned stopping rule short of n=100 for this design cell if we cannot acquire enough respondents.  This should not be an issue at all for the remaining 3 design cells (and hopefully is not an issue for this one either).

question.value: Sample characteristics of political ideology and religious view will be used to balance recruitment of each 2-characteristic combination.  Within the survey, no variables are manipulated (all subjects complete the exact same survey).

Covariates will include: age, gender, preferences for keeping up with news and religion, self-reported engagement in issues of politics and religion, self-identification of political ideology and party affiliation and religious beliefs (can cross-check against Prolific filters), favorability ratings on several political and religious groups/figures, self-reported sleepiness (Karolinska scale) and hrs slept last night.
Outcome measures will include: political and religious attitude strength and extremity of positions.  There will be a premeasure of these, as well as a post measure, which will occur before and after the key "information board" and "argument strength" tasks.  The information board task will generate data on how many of 6 arguments were self-selected for viewing (by the subject) from Conservative versus Liberal political sources (on the issue of "gun control"), as well as how many of 6 arguments are self-selected for viewing from Christian versus Atheist (or evolution-believing) sources (on the issue of "the existence or non-existence of God").  The argument strength task, rather, requires each subject to view 6 arguments balanced in their support or not of gun control and, for the religious viewpoint argument strength task, balanced in arguments promoting or not the existence of God.
The other outcome measure captured will be a validated 6-item Cognitive Reflection Task scale that will help identify subjects who tend to be more versus less reflective in their thinking style.

Items such as outcomes from the Information Board or Argument Strength task will be combined into a singular scale by combining responses.  For the Information Board task this involves simply adding the number of arguments of one viewpoint versus the other.  For argument strength, this involves adding responses with a neutral argument strength used as the mid-point "zero" score.  In this way, the composite score can be made to reflect that positive (negative) values indicate pro-gun (anti-gun) rights or pro-existence (anti-existence) of God.  The Cognitive Reflection Scale creates a combined score by totaling the number of correct responses.
Hypotheses will be tested using nonparametric tests for unconditional analysis, as well as using multi-variate econometric estimations to condition the analysis on important co-variates.

q20.value: See previous description in "variables" area of this preregistration for a description of the recoding plan for the data from the Information Board and Argument Strength tasks.  In short, responses are combined into a single metric that will indicate strength of preference for one type of information or strength of attitude towards arguments favoring a particular viewpoint.

q21.value: One-tailed tests will be used to test the hypotheses 1a, 1b, 2a, and 2b given the previous documentation of a confirmation bias.  Two-tailed tests will be used to test hypothesis 3 given the lack of a directional hypothesis in either case.  Finally, a one-tailed test will be used to test hypothesis 4 given our ex ante hypothesis that the confirmation bias is a deliberative-thought bias. (Note: this will be examined in our data using both self-reported sleepiness as well as Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT) scores as a proxy for the amount of deliberation that goes into the choice task: sleepier or lower CRT score subjects are considered to use less deliberation in the confirmation bias tasks.  We also ask participants how much thought they have put into the specific issues of "gun control" and "the existence of God".

q22.value:
An attention-check (poison pill) question is included within the survey.  Analysis will be conducted both with and without inclusion of those who fail the attention check.

Pilot data (n=10 participants) will not be analyzed for the study.  The purpose of the pilot data is to assess survey length and set compensation rate.

q24.value: One exploratory analysis to be run will examine whether more stereotypical combinations of politics and religious beliefs (e.g., Conservative and Christian, or Liberal and Non-Religious) display different confirmation bias tendencies than more mixed combinations (such as Conservative and Non-Religious, or Liberal and Christian)

summary.value: The PDF document on this project entitled "Pre-registration PDF" contains the pre-registration for this study.

registration_responses.summary: The PDF document on this project entitled "Pre-registration PDF" contains the pre-registration for this study.

q3.value: The purpose of this study to provide a comprehensive picture of the homicide-suicide situation in Hong Kong from 2000 to 2019. Since the previous study (Chan, Beh, & Broadhurst, 2003) was conducted almost two decades ago about HS in Hong Kong in 1989-1998, it is important to update the current situation with contemporary data. This project aims to look into the offender's mode of killing, the reason for offense and means of suicide (adopted from Chan, Beh, & Broadhurst, 2003). Nonetheless, this project will investigate any demographic predictors and characteristics of the offenders, including employment status, marital status, age, and gender.

q4.value: Offenders and victims tend to be related, where females and children are typically the victims of the offense, male as the offender. The nature and number of incidence is influenced by the social atmosphere (i.e. economy).

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is archival research.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: Data will be collected for any (attempted) suicidal events after the offender has murder another individual(s) in Hong Kong from 2010 to 2019. Even for the offender or victim who has survived through the incident, the event will still be counted and assessed as an HS event.

q13.value: There will not be a limitation on the sample size since it is restricted by the number of HS events happening, however, incidents from 2000 to 2019 will be assessed.

question.value: The offender's mode of killing, the reason for killing, their cause of death, employment status, marital status, as well as the offender and victim's age and gender.
I will use logistic regression for the prediction of the mode of killing, nature of the event, the reason of killing, cause of death from an offender / victim's age / gender.

q20.value:
Male will be coded as 0, female will be coded as 1.
The presence of the measured variable will be coded as 1, otherwise, 0.

q21.value: p-value should be less than or equal to 0.05

q23.value: Missing data will not be analyzed or remarked as "unknown".

registration_responses.q3: The purpose of this study to provide a comprehensive picture of the homicide-suicide situation in Hong Kong from 2000 to 2019. Since the previous study (Chan, Beh, & Broadhurst, 2003) was conducted almost two decades ago about HS in Hong Kong in 1989-1998, it is important to update the current situation with contemporary data. This project aims to look into the offender's mode of killing, the reason for offense and means of suicide (adopted from Chan, Beh, & Broadhurst, 2003). Nonetheless, this project will investigate any demographic predictors and characteristics of the offenders, including employment status, marital status, age, and gender.
registration_responses.q4: Offenders and victims tend to be related, where females and children are typically the victims of the offense, male as the offender. The nature and number of incidence is influenced by the social atmosphere (i.e. economy).
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to accessing the data
registration_responses.q13: There will not be a limitation on the sample size since it is restricted by the number of HS events happening, however, incidents from 2000 to 2019 will be assessed.
registration_responses.q20:
Male will be coded as 0, female will be coded as 1.
The presence of the measured variable will be coded as 1, otherwise, 0.
registration_responses.q21: p-value should be less than or equal to 0.05
registration_responses.q23: Missing data will not be analyzed or remarked as "unknown".
registration_responses.q8.question: This is archival research.
registration_responses.q12.question: Data will be collected for any (attempted) suicidal events after the offender has murder another individual(s) in Hong Kong from 2010 to 2019. Even for the offender or victim who has survived through the incident, the event will still be counted and assessed as an HS event.
registration_responses.q17.question: The offender's mode of killing, the reason for killing, their cause of death, employment status, marital status, as well as the offender and victim's age and gender.
registration_responses.q19.question: I will use logistic regression for the prediction of the mode of killing, nature of the event, the reason of killing, cause of death from an offender / victim's age / gender.
