q1.value: Priming Meritocracy and Dehumanization of Low-SES groups

q3.value: In the medical context, dehumanization may sometimes be advantageous, preventing health professionals from affective costs  (Harris, 2014). Yet too often people engage in dehumanization processes affecting unfavorably low status group members (Harris & Fiske, 2006;  Vaes & Paladino, 2010). Though dehumanization of low status groups has become a burgeoning area of research in social psychology (see Haslam & Loughnan, 2014; Haslam & Stratemeyer, 2016; Leyens, Demoulin, Vaes, Gaunt, & Paladino, 2007; Harris & Fiske, 2006), research about societal norms potentially influencing low SES groups’s dehumanization hasn't been addressed yet. For example, power was found to predict dehumanization in a medical decision-making context. In Lammers & Stapel (2011) study participants who had a greater personal sense of power were more likely to dehumanize a low status patient and also to endorse a more painful (and effective) treatment. Yet a significant factor known to impact on group-based distinctions has been neglected in the dehumanization research. Though there is evidence to suggest that priming Meritocracy leads to less favorable orientations toward low-status groups (Madeira et al., 2019), the potential effect of meritocracy on low SES groups dehumanization has never been demonstrated. Therefore the present study investigate whether priming meritocracy promotes dehumanization of low SES target. Specifically, we want to (a) ascertain whether meritocracy impact on medical decisions towards low SES targets, (b) investigate whether meritocracy impacts on the dehumanization of the low SES target and (c) understand whether the impact of meritocracy on medical decisions occurs through changes in a) the level of dehumanization of low-SES groups.

q4.value:
First, we predict the main effect of target SES, in that:
1) low-SES target (vs high-SES) will be more likely to receive a more unfavorable medical decision ; 
2) low SES target (vs high-SES) will be more likely to be dehumanized.

Second, we predict an interaction effect, in that low SES target will be more likely to be dehumanized, when meritocracy is salient (vs. neutral condition).

Third, the impact of target-SES on the medical decision will occur through changes in the level of low -SES target dehumanization. Particularly, when meritocracy is salient. So, we predict low-SES dehumanization to mediate the relationship between target-SES and medical decisions. And expect this mediation to be moderated by meritocracy, expecting the mediation to occur when meritocracy is salient.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
A mixed design with 3 factors between-subjects 1-factor within-subjects. 
The 3 factors between-subjects are: (1) social norms with 2 levels (neutral and meritocracy);  order of target presentation  (Low-SES first vs Low-SES second) and type of disease ( sex vs drugs); all will be counterbalanced.
The one-factor within-subjects has 2 levels (low -SES target and high-SES target).

q9.value: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the 6 conditions. We will fully randomize the order of target presentation (Low-SES first vs Low-SES second) and type of contagious (condomless sess vs Drugs consumption). To that end, blocks will be created on Qualtrics and we will add a Randomizer to randomly present one of the predetermined blocks.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Medical students, ranging from 1th to 6th medical school year, will be recruited through a server list to participate in an experiment about medical decision-making. Participants will not be paid.  If our sample size is not reached timely we anticipate asking students to recruit participants in the exchange of credits course. Participants must be medical students and having Mexican nationality.

Procedure. Participants are told that they would take part in a research study about medical decision-making processes. In the decision-making task, participants read information on Hepatitis C and on the rationalization of the treatment of the hepatitis C virus (HCV). To ensure that participants read the information, we will add an attentional check. Next, they are asked to imagine themselves as a physician, a member of a panel with the mission of recommending patients for the treatment of hepatitis C. Participants view two clinical cases.  The cases are randomized. For each clinical case, the participants are asked to what extent they would recommend the patient for the treatment of hepatitis C and  the likelihood of following the recommendations of the doctor and of responsibly taking the medication. Participants are randomly assigned to one of the two order conditions: participants either see the Low-SES (or high-SES) patient associated with (a) unprotected sex practices (condomless sex condition) or with (b) shared tubes for cocaine consumption (e.g., speedballs; the non-injectable drug use condition). Other than that, clinical cases are similar in age and health status. Afterward, participants complete sociodemographic information and briefly debriefed.

q13.value: Our target sample is 180 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 200, assuming that not all will complete the survey.

q14.value: This sample size was estimated by G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) with 80% of power to detect a medium effect size (F = .25) in an ANOVA with Repeated measures and between factors.

question.value:
In our manipulation of Meritocracy, we use a scrambled sentence task, previously pilot tested and adapted from McCoy and Major (2007). Participants are randomly assigned to one of the two conditions, the meritocracy condition or the neutral condition. In both conditions, participants are given 18 items consisting of five words and told to construct four-word sentences. Participants have five minutes to complete as many of the items as possible. In the meritocracy condition, participants complete sentences related to meritocracy beliefs (e.g., Item: ‘effort positive prosperity leads to’ Answer: ‘Effort leads to prosperity’). In the control condition, participants complete sentences unrelated to meritocracy (e.g., Item: ‘experience travel is an learning’ Answer: ‘learning is an experience’).

The socio-economic status  (SES) of the target is manipulated in the clinical vignette. Participants view two clinical vignettes depicting a fictitious patient. The patients are low- or high-SES.

The outcome variable will be:

1. Medical Recommendation. We will measure this by asking participants in a 7-points scale, from not at all (1) to very much (7) to what extent would they recommend the person for the hepatitis C treatment.

2. Blatant Dehumanization. To capture the tendency to dehumanize low-SES patients compared to High-SES patients, we will implement the Ascent of Man measure (Kteily, Bruneau, Waytz & Cotterrill, 2015). This is a blatant scale in which participants will need to rate the extent each patient scores on a scale from 0 (“less evolved”) to 100 (“more evolved). Participants will rate also the filler case (middle-SES patient), but this would not be included in the analysis.

3. Medical Compliance. We will measure this by asking participants in a 7-points scale, from not at all (1) to highly (7)  how likely would this patient be to a) Responsibly follow treatment recommendations? and b) Comply with medical advice?

Secondary Variables. 

Familiarity with HepC. we will measure this by asking participants to what extent are they familiar with hepatitis C and the available treatments, using a 7-points rating scale, ranging from 1= Not at all to 7 = Very.

Endorsement of meritocracy. We will assess the endorsement of meritocracy with items used by Madeira (2019).

Subjective SES. We will measure this by presenting participants with a picture of a 9-rung ladder. They are asked to place themselves on the ladder (check a rung) based on where they stand compared to other persons in Mexico in terms of income, education, and occupation (on a scale ranging from 1 (lowest rung) to 9 (highest rung).

We will use a 2x2x2x2 repeated measures ANOVA with one-factor within-subjects and the remaining between-subjects to analyze our results.

The within factor has two levels and will be called Target-SES. The within-subjects variables will be a medical recommendation, medical compliance, and blatant dehumanization.

The between factors have two levels each: social norms (control vs meritocracy); target order and type of contagious. 

We will  test the main effect of:
Target SES  on each DV

We will test the following interactions 

TargetSES * Order. 
TargetSES * Type of contagious. 
TargetSES * social norms
TargetSES * Type of contagious* social norms 
TargetSES * Order * Type of contagious * social norms

Follow-up tests:


TargetSES * Order * Type of contagious * social norms

We will test the following mediations:

TargetSES ----- Target Dehumanization ----- Target Medical Recommendation 
TargetSES ----- Target Dehumanization ----- Target Medical Compliance  

 If dehumanization mediates the relationship between target-SES and the medical outcome variable, then we will test whether this process occurs differently across the two levels of the between-factor, social norms (control vs meritocracy):

VI=TargetSES 
VMED=Target Dehumanization 
VMOD = Social Norms
VD 1= Target Medical Recommendation 
VD2=Target Medical Compliance 

We plan on using a manipulation check. We plan to conduct a  one-way ANOVA, with meritocracy prime as the factor and meritocracy scale as the DV.

q21.value: We will use the standard p= .05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value:
We will verify the number of correct responses on the priming task. Participants with error rate of 50 % will be not included in the analysis.

Overly consistent responses will be checked.
Extreme outliers (- 2 / + 2 above the mean) will be not included in the analysis.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete any of the three DVs, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q25.value:
Harris, L. T., & Fiske, S. T. (2006). Dehumanizing the lowest of the low: Neuro-imaging responses to extreme out-groups. Psychological Science, 17, 847-853

Vaes, J., & Paladino, M. P. (2010). The uniquely human content of stereotypes. Group Processes & Intergroup Relations, 13(1), 23-39.

Haslam, N., & Loughnan, S. (2014). Dehumanization and infrahumanization. Annual review of psychology, 65, 399-423.

 Haslam, N., & Stratemeyer, M. (2016). Recent research on dehumanization. Current Opinion in Psychology, 11, 25-29.

Leyens, J. P., Demoulin, S., Vaes, J., Gaunt, R., & Paladino, M. P. (2007). Infra‐humanization: The wall of group differences. Social Issues and Policy Review, 1(1), 139-172. 

Lammers, J., & Stapel, D. A. (2011). Power increases dehumanization. Group Processes & Intergroup Relations, 14(1), 113-126.

Madeira, F., Costa-Lopes, R., Dovidio, J. F., Freitas, G., & Mascarenhas, M. (2019). Primes and consequences: a systematic review of meritocracy in intergroup relations. Frontiers in psychology, 10, 2007.
